content.text: Discipline serves an educational purpose, promoting self-governance and ethical decision-making. The framework aligns with Indonesian child protection regulations and integrates Islamic educational values where applicable.

content.title: Core Principles
items: Restorative Focus: Prioritizing repairing harm and restoring relationships.
Due Process: Ensuring every student has the right to be heard.
Proportionality: Matching consequences to the severity of behavior.
Consistency: Applying expectations equitably across all students.
Cultural Sensitivity: Respecting diverse backgrounds while maintaining universal standards.
Student Voice: Involving students in developing expectations and resolving conflicts.
Positive Reinforcement: Recognizing positive behavior alongside addressing misconduct.
Transparency: Clearly communicating rules and consequences.

content.text: The discipline framework supports the development of Schoolwide Learner Outcomes (SLOs) and integrates Profil Pelajar Pancasila (P8) character competencies.
Student conduct and discipline intersect with safeguarding, ensuring the safety and wellbeing of all students.
The Student Code of Conduct applies to all students and governs behavior in various contexts including school hours, school-sponsored activities, and online interactions.

content.title: Behavioral Expectations Matrix
items: Respect for Self: Maintain personal dignity and make healthy choices.
Respect for Others: Treat all community members with kindness and courtesy.
Respect for Learning: Come prepared and engage actively in lessons.
Respect for Environment: Care for school property and maintain cleanliness.
Safety and Security: Follow safety protocols and report concerns.
Digital Citizenship: Use technology responsibly and ethically.

content.text: Behavioral expectations are developmentally appropriate across different age groups, with clear communication through handbooks, orientation programs, and classroom agreements.

subsections.title: Classification of Behaviors and Progressive Consequences

content.text: Behaviors are classified into four levels based on severity and impact, ensuring proportionate responses.

content.title: Levels of Behavior
rows: Referral to SC Coordinator, parent contact.

content.text: Factors affecting classification and consequences include intent, frequency, and student history.
Disciplinary procedures adhere to principles of presumption of innocence, confidentiality, and timely response.

content.title: Investigation Process
steps: Initial Report: Staff report incidents using the Incident Report Form.
Initial Assessment: SC Coordinator reviews the report.
Evidence Collection: Gather statements and documentation.
Student Interview: Interview the student involved.
Parent Notification: Inform parents of the investigation.
Analysis and Recommendation: Analyze evidence and recommend actions.
Decision and Communication: Authority makes the final decision.

content.text: Suspension can be in-school or out-of-school, with specific procedures for each.

content.title: Expulsion Process
steps: Principal Recommendation: Prepare a written recommendation.
Discipline Committee Review: Committee convenes to review documentation.
Hearing: Student and parents invited to present their case.
Committee Deliberation: Committee decides on expulsion or alternative consequences.
Yayasan Board Decision: Final decision made by the Yayasan Board.

content.text: Students and parents have the right to appeal Level 3 and Level 4 decisions based on procedural errors, new evidence, or disproportionate consequences.

content.title: Appeal Procedures
steps: Written Appeal Submission: Submit appeal within 5 school days.
Review of Appeal: GM/Foundation Representative reviews the appeal.
Appeal Decision: Written response provided within 10 school days.

content.text: Restorative practices focus on repairing harm and restoring relationships rather than punitive measures.

content.title: Restorative Approaches
items: Community Circles: Regular meetings to build relationships.
Restorative Conversations: Dialogue between those harmed and those causing harm.
Peer Mediation: Trained students help peers resolve conflicts.

content.title: Key Policies
items: Anti-Bullying Policy: Strict prohibition of all forms of bullying.
Academic Integrity Policy: Expectations for honesty in academic work.
Technology and Digital Citizenship Policy: Guidelines for responsible technology use.
Search and Seizure Policy: Authority to conduct searches for safety.
Substance Abuse Policy: Prohibition of drugs and alcohol on school premises.

content.text: The Code of Conduct applies 24/7 for boarding students, with additional expectations for dormitory behavior.

content.title: Dormitory-Specific Expectations
items: Daily schedule compliance including prayer times and study periods.
Maintaining cleanliness and respecting roommates' belongings.
Proper authorization for leaving campus and adherence to curfews.

content.text: All behavioral incidents must be documented in EduNav for tracking and improvement.

content.title: Documentation Requirements
items: Incident Reports: Detailed descriptions of incidents.
Conference Notes: Records of meetings regarding behavior.
Warning Letters: Documentation of serious misconduct.

content.title: Key Roles
items: Principal: Overall accountability for discipline implementation.
General Manager/Foundation Representative: Oversight of policy implementation.
School Culture Coordinator: Day-to-day behavior management leadership.
Homeroom Teacher: First point of contact for behavior concerns.
Counselor: Provides support and facilitates restorative processes.

content.text: Staff receive training on discipline policy and restorative practices to ensure effective implementation.

content.title: Training Components
items: Annual policy refresher for all staff.
Restorative practices training for teachers.
Cultural sensitivity training for understanding diverse backgrounds.

content.text: The policy is reviewed annually with input from stakeholders and analysis of behavioral data.

content.title: Review Process
items: Gather feedback from stakeholders.
Analyze behavioral data for trends.
Finalize revisions and communicate updates.

subsections.title: Key Evidence and Artifacts for Accreditation

content.title: Documentation for Accreditation
items: Student Code of Conduct with parent acknowledgment.
Incident logs and behavior data reports.
Sample investigation files demonstrating due process.

content.text: The policy aligns with CIS/WASC standards, Indonesian regulations, and Cambridge requirements.
